column1: '''Ori''' was one of the thirteen [[Dwarves]] of [[Thorin and Company
column2: Thorin's company]] who journeyed to [[Lonely Mountain
column4: dragon]] [[Smaug]].  After the death of Smaug, Ori lived at the Lonely Mountain<ref name="Meetings">{{FR
column5: II1}}</ref> until he went to [[Moria]] as part of [[Balin]]'s ill-fated attempt to re-take the ancient mansions of the Dwarves.<ref name="Bridge">{{FR

column1: Ori's parentage is unknown, although he was a remote kinsman of Thorin and a member of the [[House of Durin]].<ref name="Durin"/>  His birth year is also unknown.  However, in [[Bilbo Baggins]]' account of the quest to Erebor, it was said that the brothers [[Fíli]] and [[Kíli]] were the youngest of the thirteen "by some fifty years"<ref name="Hill">{{H
column2: Hill}}</ref> and that after Thorin had been captured, [[Balin]] was "the eldest left".<ref>{{H
column3: Barrels}}</ref>  Since Fíli was born in {{TA
column6: n}},<ref name="Durin"/> this would put Ori's birth between 2809 and {{TA
column8: n}}, and he would have been between 132 and 178 years old during the quest to Erebor.  Ori was a member of the [[House of Durin]] and probably lived in the [[Blue Mountains]] with [[Thorin]] after he began living there following the loss of [[Thráin

column3: TA}}</ref> Ori was one of the five Dwarves in the fourth group to arrive at [[Bag End]].  He wore a grey hood.  During the evening when Thorin called for music, Ori (along with [[Dori]] and [[Nori]]) played the flute.<ref>{{H

column1: When [[Gandalf]] was telling the story of the company's adventures to [[Beorn]], Ori and Nori were the second pair of Dwarves to arrive.<ref>{{H

column5: Joona Kujanen - ''Last Moments'']]Ori fought in and survived the [[Battle of Five Armies]].  He was given his share of the treasure by [[Dáin Ironfoot]], and made his home in Erebor.<ref>{{H

column2: 2989}}<ref name="TA"/> Ori (and Óin) had followed Balin with a [[Balin's Colony
column3: colony]] of Dwarves in an attempt to reclaim their ancient mansions of [[Moria
column4: Khazad-dûm]], which were already occupied by the [[Orcs
column6: Council}}</ref>  At first the colony did well, but [[Third Age 2994
column7: less than five years later]] Balin was killed, the Orcs returned and took the [[Great Gates
column8: East-gate]], and Óin's group that he took west to the [[Doors of Durin
column9: West-gate]] was destroyed except for a few.

column3: Page from the [[Book of Mazarbul]] written by Ori in [[Tengwar]].]]

column1: Ori retreated to the [[Chamber of Mazarbul]] where [[Balin's Tomb]] was laid.  He wrote the last pages in the [[Book of Mazarbul]] before he and the last few remaining Dwarves perished during a [[Last Stand of Balin's Colony
column2: final stand]].<ref name="Bridge"/> As Ori knew there was no hope to escape, he continued writing in the book, hoping that someone would find it, and would know what happened to them.<ref>{{PM

column1: When [[Frodo Baggins]] came to [[Rivendell]] he met [[Glóin]], who delighted in telling the hobbit about the doings of the renewed dwarf-kingdom in the Lonely Mountain.  But when Frodo asked about Ori, [[Balin]], and [[Óin]] (also members of Thorin and Company), Glóin's face darkened and he said that he did not know.  In fact, their fate was largely why the Dwarves had come to Rivendell at that time, to seek advice.<ref name="Meetings"/>

During the [[War of the Ring]], the [[Fellowship of the Ring]] journeyed through [[Moria]] and discovered the book that contained the records of the expedition.  The last lines were written by Ori, as recognized by [[Gimli]] due to Ori's recognizable large, bold handwriting using [[Tengwar]] (Gimli also said that Ori could write well and speedily).<ref name="Bridge"/>
Óri is a dwarf from the ''[[Völuspá
column2: Dvergatal]]''. The name means "Violent".<ref>Chester Nathan Gould, "Dwarf-Names: A Study in Old Icelandic Religion", published in ''Publications of the Modern Language Association of America'', Vol 44 (1929), issue #4, pp. 939-967</ref>

column1: Ori is said to be the cousin of Dori and Nori in Tolkien's 1966 notes, despite the popular belief that he is their brother. It is also confirmed that he wears a grey hood.<ref>{{HH

column2: Thorin Oakenshield]] only travels with an unnamed guard and the princess of Dale.<ref name="Deitch">{{webcite

column1: :Ori's voice is provided by [[Jack DeLeon]]. However, he only ever speaks in unison with the rest of the Dwarves.

column4: articlename=Production begins in New Zealand on The Hobbit
column7: accessed=23-Dec-2011}}</ref> A description of Ori in ''The Hobbit'' films was released by the studio:

column2: Younger brother to Nori and Dori, Ori is a talented artist, and can often be found drawing and writing in his journal. It is Ori who chronicles much of the journey through The Wild to the shores of the Long Lake and the slopes of The Lonely Mountain. Polite and well-bred, he is used to be being bossed around by his older brother Dori and is usually biddable, although occasionally he can surprise his fellow companions with his courage and determination.

column1: :While in the book [[Fíli]] and [[Kíli]] are said to be the youngest of the 13 Dwarves in Thorin's company by at least 50 years, Ori is instead the youngest in the ''Hobbit'' films.
:No actor is specified for the role of Ori.

:Ori is omitted; Thorin is the only companion of the player, [[Bilbo Baggins]].<ref>[http://www.worldofspectrum.org/showmag.cgi?mag=ZXComputing/Issue8304/Pages/ZXComputing830400076.jpg ''ZX Computing'', 8304 (April/May 1983), p. 76] (accessed 24 March 2011)</ref>
:No actor is credited for the role of Ori.

:There are two dwarves that have the name Ori. Foreman Ori stands near the Silver Deep Mine in Thorin's Gate. There is also a Captain Ori that the player controls during a session play entitled "We Cannot Get Out".<ref>[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pyIFrUbkYAE LOTRO - We Cant Get Out Session play instance (video)] at [http://www.youtube.com/ YouTube.com] (accessed 27 May 2011)</ref> Since the events of the game happen after {{TA
column2: 2994}} and the session play is a flashback of the fight in the Twenty-First Hall that happened during {{TA
column3: 2994}}, Foreman Ori must be a character created specifically for the game, while Captain Ori is Turbine's adaptation of the Ori described in Tolkien's writings.
